ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RETRENCHED WORKERS

(Retraining for alternative jobs)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong -

    1. To ask the Minister for Labour whether, in the light of the economic down turn and the possibility of more workers being retrenched, the Government has taken any steps to retrain workers, who are retrenched, for alternative jobs.

    Mr Bernard Chen (West Coast): Question No. 1.

    The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): There are presently several Government-supported schemes to assist retrenched workers in enhancing their employability.

    Under the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP) funded by Government and managed by the National Trades Union Congress, employers who recruit retrenched workers could apply for training grant to upgrade the skills of the workers so that they could meet the needs of the new jobs. The SRP is targetted at less educated workers in their 30s and 40s, who may face greater difficulty seeking re-employment. Government's support is up to 80% of course fees to be paid by the Productivity and Standards Board (PSB) from the Skills Development Fund (SDF) and up to 70% of absentee payroll subject to a maximum of $4.20 per trainee-hour, paid by EDB.

    Sir, I have been informed that to date, 1,230 workers have gone through or are undergoing certifiable training under the Skills Redevelopment Programme. Of these workers, more than 50% are above the age of 40 and approximately 70% have below Secondary 2 education.

    Assistance is also granted to the retrenched workers under the tripartite "Back to Work" Programme launched in September 1996 by my Ministry together with the Productivity and Standards Board, the National Trades Union Congress and the Singapore National Employers Federation. The assistance

Column: 587

includes helping the retrenched workers find suitable jobs and encouraging employers to employ retrenched workers through a training grant which enables the workers to undergo Core Skills and Job Skills Training.

    Core Skills Training includes confidence building, personal effectiveness and basic computer literacy. The training is fully supported by the SDF which provides a flat grant of $350 per trainee including an allowance of $100 to each trainee to help defray his meals and transport expenses. Job Skills Training is for the purpose of helping the workers to acquire specific skills required for the jobs. For such training, SDF will provide enhanced funding up to 80% of the course fees for external training programme or $4 per trainee hour for on-the-job training.

    Sir, in anticipation of more retrenchments in the coming months as a result of the regional financial crisis and slowdown in the economy, my Ministry has recently set up a Tripartite Panel on Retrenched Workers comprising representatives from the EDB, NTUC, SNEF, PSB and my Ministry itself to assist retrenched workers seek re-employment. The Panel will also encourage employers to take advantage of available training incentives to improve the skills of their workers during the lull period. Workers, on the other hand, are urged to take training and skill upgrading seriously so that they can remain employable especially during an economic slowdown.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): As I understand from the Minister, 80% of the cost will be funded from the Government. Is it the intention that the retrenched workers should bear the 20%?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, under the SRP which is targetted at the older and less educated workers, we have identified workers who may be retrenched and who need alternative jobs. The programme is available to them while they are still being employed by the existing employer and, as a result, with

Column: 588

Government's support, 80% of the cost of retraining them for some other jobs would be borne by Government, while the other 20% would be borne by the existing employers. If they are already recruited by a new employer, the new employer can take up the other 20% of the cost.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask how much of this has been brought to the notice of the workers?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the SRP is a very well publicised programme. Since December 1996, when it was first launched by the National Trades Union Congress, they have done a lot to publicise the programme, ie, the benefits and advantages of participating in the programme. In fact, if the Member had taken the trouble to read the NTUC News dated 6th March ---

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I do not read it!

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: I think the Member should from time to time read it to keep himself apprised of the good work that is being done by the NTUC and the massive effort that the NTUC has been involved in in trying to help the workers. There are a lot of details in the report and they are all publicised. It is also duly reported in the media what NTUC has been doing to help workers to upgrade their skills. In fact, I would like to mention that in this report of 6th March, it was stated that they have signed up quite a large number of employers under the new phase to launch further Skills Redevelopment Programme for their workers and currently, a total of 76 companies are participating and 5,000 workers are involved in the scheme.

MEASURES TO SAFEGUARD AGAINST MASSIVE BLACKOUT


    2. Mr S Iswaran asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what measures already exist, and what additional measures are needed, to safeguard against the occurrence of a massive blackout like that which recently affected Auckland, New Zealand.

Column: 589



    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Tang Guan Seng) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): The cause of the recent cable failures in Auckland, New Zealand, has yet to be established. According to some reports, they were probably caused by the abnormal drying up of the soil surrounding the cables due to the prolonged hot and dry summer. Consequently, heat could not be conducted away from the heavily loaded cables fast enough. The cable temperature could have risen well above its design specifications, leading to the cascading cable failures.

    Such form of cable failure is unlikely in Singapore as PowerGrid Ltd, the electricity network operator in Singapore, has instituted the following measures:

    (a) Firstly, PowerGrid has built a strong transmission network. For example, the CBD network is supplied by multiple 230 kV sources and is interconnected to provide contingencies to take care of unforeseen cable failures or damages.

    (b) Secondly, PowerGrid's 230 kV transmission cables are installed with backfill designed to ensure efficient heat dissipation and avoid thermal overloading.

    (c) Thirdly, with advances in technology, Distributed Temperature Sensing (DTS) cables are now available which enable real-time monitoring of the actual cable temperature. PowerGrid has installed such DTS cable on a 400 kV cable and will be installing it on two additional 400 kV cables and future 230 kV cables.

    PowerGrid has a rolling 10-year development plan to expand and renew the network to meet Singapore's electricity demand in a reliable, secure and timely manner. For example, PowerGrid is currently developing a new 230 kV substation at Peng Nguan Street to reinforce the network in anticipation of the CBD's rising demand in the years to come.

ELECTRONIC ROAD PRICING

(Deferment of implementation)


    3. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Communications whether he will defer the implementation of the Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) system after 1st

Column: 590

April 1998, in view of the current difficult economic conditions which will impact local businesses.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, road pricing is a major pillar in our long-term strategy to keep our roads free-flowing. Our roads are our economic arteries. If they get clogged, transport costs will go up, businesses will lose time and money, and the productivity of our workers will suffer.

    Road pricing has been implemented in Singapore since 1975 with the Area Licensing Scheme, and recently with the Road Pricing Scheme on our expressways. It has been successful in managing the traffic on our roads. But more needs to be done because on one hand our vehicle population is growing, yet on the other hand our land area remains constant.

    The Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) will replace both the ALS and the RPS schemes. It is more flexible, more efficient and in the long run, more cost effective. It marks a shift in emphasis, from charging for vehicle ownership to charging for usage. It will encourage more judicious usage and keep our roads congestion free.

    There is no reason to delay the start of ERP on 1st April because of the current economic situation. In fact, the current slow-down should spur us to implement policies to strengthen our advantages, like our transport system, in order to maintain our economic competitiveness. The ERP and the new vehicle tax structure revealed on 4th March serve this objective.

    The new tax structure and the package of ERP rebates benefit most motorists in general and businesses in particular. For example, Additional Registration Fee (ARF) for tourist buses will be reduced from 55% of Open Market Value (OMV) to 5% of OMV, Registration Fee (RF) for goods vehicles will be reduced by as much as $13,000, and ARF for engineering plant vehicles will be waived. The annual road tax of most commercial vehicles will also be reduced substantially, by as much as $2,000. Where taxes have been increased, we will phase in the increase

Column: 591

over three years. To help businesses adjust to the ERP system, we will phase-in the ERP charges for all commercial vehicles over the next three to four years. In effect, many vehicle owners will pay lower road pricing charges than what they pay today.

    Commercial vehicle owners and fleet operators will benefit even more if they exercise their ingenuity and discretion. They can reduce their ERP bill by planning their routes and scheduling their delivery times carefully, and pooling transport resources where possible.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether his Ministry has done any studies or comparison for companies that are involved in the transport trade, ie, companies that are going to use a lot of vehicles for transportation? What would be the impact of the ERP on the total expenses before and after the implementation of the ERP programme?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, for companies that are involved in transport and logistics like freight forwarding, there will be a substantial reduction in their upfront cost as well as in their road tax. But on the other hand, the ERP will add cost to the usage of the roads. How much additional costs they will incur as a result of ERP is difficult for us to say because it depends very much on their usage. But ultimately, ERP is a tool for us to help businesses to readjust the way of doing business and to encourage them to use the roads more judiciously, as I said. In the long run, if they succeed in doing so, it will even be more beneficial to them. Indeed, companies like the bus companies and the taxi companies have already started to make use of technology, to make use of new ways of operating their business in order to adjust to the ERP. In so doing, they will reap not only the full benefits of the upfront tax reductions but they will also help to reduce their ERP bill.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee: May I also ask the Minister that since the ERP programme is going to be revenue neutral over the

Column: 592

longer term, in effect, would it not actually be loading more onto companies that have to be involved in the transport trade compared to what they are now, because they are even now loaded against in terms of usage? But after the implementation of the ERP, the loading could even be heavier.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, as I said, if everything remains the same, if transport companies continue to run their business in the same way without making any adjustment, then the answer is yes, there would be additional cost to them. But this is precisely the reason why we are implementing a new system which is charging for usage rather than charging for ownership. Because there is now a rebalancing of the structure and there is now a shift of charges from ownership to usage, there will be, at the very beginning, upfront savings for these companies that the Member talks about. It is now a question of how those companies adjust their business in order to try and keep as much as possible of those savings that have been given to them.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Will the Minister agree that motorcycles are used by the working class and people with low incomes to get to work? In view of the possible pay cuts, even in basic pay, and their loss of income, why should the Ministry not consider deferring the implementation for motorcycles at least, until the situation improves?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the Member obviously has not read the newspapers or the LTA webpages, in the same way that he has not read the NTUC News. I would recommend that he does so before he asks this question, because if he had, then he would realise that in fact 90% of the motorcyclists, with the phasing in of road taxes and with the ERP rebates that will be given to them in the first few years, will actually either be paying lower road taxes or no road tax.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, can I ask the Minister whether the Ministry has done any survey on the impact on the cost of goods and services to consumers with the implementation of ERP?

Column: 593



    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, we have not done any detailed surveys on the impact of ERP on goods and services. But the Ministry of Trade and Industry has given us an indication that, all things being equal, there will be a marginal impact on the cost of doing business. Indeed as a result of the massive tax rebates that have been given to businesses, particularly businesses involved in transportation, freight forwarding and so on, hopefully there will be some passing back of those savings to the consumers.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, since the Minister intends to implement the system anyway, can I can ask why do we not bring the implementation date forward to the 1st April? The scheme has already started to create a lot of confusion to the motor traders. Since we plan to implement it, why do we not implement it on 1st April?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: May I ask the Member what confusion he is talking about?

    Mr Inderjit Singh: Especially in the area of commercial vehicles, with the registration fee coming down by a drastic amount, a lot of companies that have placed orders for vehicles are waiting or cancelling their orders. This has actually created problems for motor traders, and there is a wait-and-see attitude. In my opinion, since we have decided to implement the scheme, we could bring forward the implementation date.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the package of tax reductions and the introduction of ERP was done as a total package. In other words, the implementation of ERP is actually going to be effective in a very small way on 1st April, a very small way, but in a more widespread way from 1st September. Therefore, the LTA formulated this package of measures to also be effective from 1st September.

    As regards motorists holding back their purchases, as far as those who already have COEs in hand are concerned, what I would term old COEs, there is really no reason for them to hold back their purchases because those with old COEs will not be allowed to register their vehicles under the new tax regime. That

Column: 594

would be unfair to those who have already registered using the old COEs. Old COEs already available have to be used to register vehicles using the old tax regime. So there is still business to be done.

    As regards people holding back purchases of new vehicles, the Motor Traders Association and other parties have made representations to the LTA. The LTA is now studying these representations and it will consider these views and an announcement will be made one way or another very soon.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, is the Minister aware that motorcyclists will eventually pay higher charges for road usage? The fact is that they will have to pay much higher road tax after the phasing in of road tax after five years. In view of the motorcyclists' income, is the Minister of the view that the system is equitable to them?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: The Ministry has looked at the position of motorcyclists very carefully because we realise very well that people who own motorcycles are people who generally belong to the lower income group and who need to use their motorcycles for business. The fact is that more than 80% of motorcyclists today do not pass through any ALS or RPS point. This finding is based on surveys as well as on the sale of ALS and RPS coupons. In other words, 86% of motorcyclists do not pass through any of these points. What that means is that any rebates and any tax savings that will arise as a result of this package will be beneficial to them. It will go straight to their pockets because they do not have to pay anything upfront.

    Secondly, another 10% of motorcyclists pass through the ALS or RPS points once. So, if we implement ERP and if the rates are more or less the same as what they are today, again, there is really no difference from what the situation is today. And any rebates that they get will also go straight to their pockets. So it is the very small group of people, about 5% or so, who use the RPS and ALS very often, yes, they will have to incur higher cost. But as I said, this is the purpose of the road pricing scheme. This is the

Column: 595

purpose of electronic road pricing which encourages people to save and penalises people who use our roads during congested hours more heavily. It is precisely for that reason that we are implementing ERP. It is not to make the scheme revenue neutral for each and every motorist or motorcyclist. Therefore, it is incumbent on companies and motorcyclists to now relook at the way they are doing business. That is the whole idea of the scheme. It is not meant to be a painless scheme for everybody. If that were the case, we might as well not have implemented it, because this scheme is meant for people to change their driving habits. But in the formulation of the scheme, we have taken pains to make sure that the pain for motorcyclists is minimised, and we have done so in several ways.

    We have looked at the PCU ratings. We have looked at how motorcyclists should be taxed in relation to cars. We have taken the smallest number to compute their road tax. We have looked at small motorcycles as opposed to big motorcycles. We have looked at the motorcyclist who owns a 200 cc motorcycle and below and taxed him differently from somebody, say, who owns a Harley Davidson, and we phase in the increases, if any, over three years. All this, taken together with the road tax rebate and phase-in, means that effectively 99% of motorcyclists actually do not pay any more taxes. In fact, if you look at the calculations which we have done, motorcyclists owning vehicles below 350 cc actually will pay zero road tax over the new few years. Five years later, they would have adjusted. But, as I said, this scheme is not meant to be a standstill for motorcycle taxes. That I must admit.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, if I may revert to the Minister's reply to my question on delaying the implementation of the ERP for motorcycles, would he agree that his answer is really no answer? Because in the case of road tax, they might probably have already paid or it may not be due for some time. But in the case of ERP, it is a

Column: 596

present-day charge, that they keep paying every day when they have to go through the gantry.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as I have already indicated, the majority of motorcyclists, in fact, over 80% do not pay. 10% pay once, which they are already paying today. So the Member is talking about the 5% of motorcyclists who use it regularly. As I explained to his colleague, Mr Low Thia Khiang, it is up to the motorcyclist himself to start to readjust his way of operation. If you are a motorcyclist who use the congested roads in the CBD five times, 10 times or 20 times, why should the rest of the motorcyclists who do not use the roads have to pay? Why do they not get the benefits?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: They may need to go through it.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: If he needs to, then he pays for it.

    Dr Vasoo: Sir, as a follow up to my earlier question, if the school bus operators were to increase their charges unnecessarily, what action would the Ministry take?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the school bus operators will also not incur higher taxes. They will also incur lower taxes; again, as part of the total package. So there is really no reason for them to increase any of the bus fees, for at least this year and the next few years.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, would the Minister agree that eventually the motorcyclists will be paying more than what they are paying now? With the phasing in of higher road tax for the motorcyclists, what is the rationale for phasing in a much higher road tax scheme than at present?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, basically, when we did this exercise, we started off with a blank sheet of paper. I said in Parliament, and I said to the Motor Traders Association and various interest groups, that this is an opportunity for us to start off from basics, to see how different types of vehicles, different sizes, different cc, different seating capacity, how much each vehicle should pay for using our roads and for causing wear and tear of our

Column: 597

roads. We started off with a blank piece of paper. We did not look at the existing tax structure. How much should a big car pay as opposed to a small car? How much should a bus pay relative to a motorcycle and so on and so forth? There is a whole range of vehicles registered on our roads today, 680,000 of them, ranging from very small 100 cc bikes, all the way to very heavy goods vehicles, the semi-trailers and so on.

    We are starting off, as I said, with a blank sheet of paper. We are looking at the right tax that each vehicle should pay based on (1) traffic considerations; and (2) based on what I would call social equity considerations, meaning if you drive a bigger car, you should actually be paying a higher tax than a smaller car. If you ride a bigger motorcycle, you should be paying more than a smaller motorcycle. We put all these things together and we came up with a basis for charging different vehicles. In the process, we realised that for some vehicles, they should be paying lower tax, eg, goods vehicles. For other vehicles, they should be paying higher tax. For example, motor-cycles. Motorcycles' tax has not been changed for decades. Some of them pay $20 a year in tax, which also has not been changed for decades. But that is where we are today.

    How do we go from where we are today to what each vehicle should rightly pay based on traffic and social considerations? For all those who are going to pay less, there is no problem. It is a question of charging the new rate for them and they will enjoy the savings. Good luck to them. But those who are paying more, we have taken the decision that we will phase in these increases where there is an increase, and the motorcyclists belong to this category that they will have to pay higher road tax. That is a fact based on their contribution to road usage and other considerations like social equity and so on. So a 1600 cc bike or a 1200 cc bike will pay $620 a year instead of $300 a year for those big luxury bikes. A 400 cc bike will pay $180 a year instead of $80 a year, an increase of $100 a year. The smallest bike, say, the Honda 125 cc , instead of paying

Column: 598

$30 a year, will have to pay $100 eventually. So motorcyclists should be paying $100, $180 and $620 relative to other vehicles on the road. That is how we derive the new tax structure.

    To minimise the pain and to phase in the increases, we have done it over three years. On top of that, we are giving the ERP rebates. You put all these things together, as I said, the net result is that motorcyclists and many other vehicle owners will over the next couple of years actually be paying less road tax than what they are paying today. Of course, yes, this will be phased in. Motorcyclists will have to adjust to these increases over three years in paying the new taxes. But that is because, as I said, under the new tax regime, this is what they should rightly be paying. We have not adjusted the tax rates for many, many years. This is the overall review that we are undertaking and this is the net result of that review. But we have recognised that motorcyclists belong to several different categories. The bulk of the motorcyclists in Singapore are 200 cc and below. For them, we are actually charging them a tax which is less than what they should actually be paying. So we have also shifted that downwards. For 1000 cc bikes and above, we have made no adjustments. No special consideration for them. They are paying the correct taxes for motorcycles relative to cars.

    So with these adjustments, with the phasing in, and with an appropriate choice of the PCU unit, we believe that we have adopted a fair, consistent and rational basis for taxes for motorcycles as well as for all other vehicles. This is the total package that we are implementing together with the ERP.

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Cheng San): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I seek a clarification from the Minister for Communications regarding revenue neutrality for this exercise. I read from the Minister for Finance's Statement that overall the Government expects to achieve revenue neutrality for this exercise in about eight years. Is this the target set and whether in fact the new charges levied will be reviewed and increased or decreased depending on the target set in terms of

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, the official GDP forecast for this year has a very wide range, 2.5% to 4.5%.     There are four main features of this year's Budget. First, it is a conservative budget aimed at achieving a small surplus. Second, there are no major tax cuts. The revenue loss from the 15% property tax rebate for commercial and industrial properties is estimated to be $145 million. Column: 630

$2.68 billion. In short, as the Minister has said, we have enough resources to activate further off-Budget measures.

Column: 631

1988. While the unit business cost index as a whole has increased by 26%, Government rates and fees, which include property tax payments, increased by 93%, or nearly doubled since 1988. While businesses are all scrambling to cut costs this year, Government charges should not contribute to costs.

In other words, except for 1996, the actual budget surplus, since the new system of accounting was published from 1990, has been larger than the estimated budget surplus. It has occurred since 1990, except for the year 1996, and I would urge the Government that it does not happen for this particular year.

    My last point is that one of the major lessons that we can learn from this slowdown is the need to develop resilience in the face of international economic shocks.

    The current slowdown is a painful reminder that there is no guarantee of economic growth in any economic system, whether capitalist or planned. The global economy will continue to exhibit

Column: 632

    The Singapore economy has experienced an economic slowdown only twice since independence - in 1975, where growth was 4.1%, and in 1985, with a growth rate of -1.6%.

    The world recession which began in 1974 worsened in the first half of 1975. The OECD growth rate for 1975 was -2�%. World trade in real terms declined by 12% in 1975, and the volume of imports by OECD countries fell by 10%.

    And yet in spite of the world recession, the Singapore economy grew by 4.1%. This was in large part due to the diversification of the economy. While manufacturing declined by 2%, the services sectors, in particular, transport, storage and communication; and finance and business services sector, provided 88% of the growth in GDP in 1975.

    Similarly, in this current economic slowdown, it is expected that those sectors with final output destined for the US and Europe, namely, manufacturing will fare better than sectors which are regionally-oriented, namely, services such as tourism, retail and healthcare. Just like an investor, an undue concentration in any one sector or market could cause us to be vulnerable to upturns and downturns in that sector or market. Within each sector, there should also be sufficient diversification in terms of industries and export markets in order to develop resilience in our economy.

    In 1985, the world economy grew by 3% as did the growth in world trade. The US economy slowed down compared to 1984, but still grew by 2.4%. In other words, in 1985, the external environment was not unfavourable. But in spite of that, Singapore suffered a recession. One main

Column: 633

    The lesson we learn from the 1985 recession is the importance of sustaining domestic competitiveness. The 43% rise in unit labour cost in 1980-1984 was one major factor which tipped the scales and caused the recession instead of a mere slowdown as occurred in 1975.

    In short, the recipe for developing resilience is sustained competitiveness combined with diversification.

I also hope that the Government will not consider 2.5% growth too high to activate such off-Budget measures. There is no need for us to suffer unnecessarily this time around.

    4. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for Labour whether his Ministry will consider making sub-contractors solely responsible for the foreign workers whom they employ instead of the current practice of making main contractors jointly responsible for these foreign workers who are beyond the control of the main contractors.

    Dr Lee Boon Yang:

    Work Permits are issued to subcontractors on the support of main contractors for their projects. The main contractors are thus partially responsible for the foreign workers brought in by their subcontractors to work on their projects. However, in the past, some main contractors had not exercised vigilance in the support of their subcontractors' work permit applications. Their careless endorsement of the subcontractors' work permit applications allowed some unscrupulous subcontractors to either inflate their foreign worker needs, or submit applications using false contracts. As a result, they operate as labour suppliers and bring in foreign workers, receive commission, default on levy payments and even abandon the workers, resulting in a host of social problems.

    To stem this abuse, the Ministry had decided in December 1997 to refer subcontractors' work permit applications to main contractors for verification and hold main contractors jointly responsible for any workers abandoned by their subcontractors. This encouraged main contractors to scrutinise their subcontractors' work permit applications. It also emphasised the important role of main contractors to ensure the proper employment of foreign construction workers by their subcontractors. The measure has met with some success. Since its implementation, approximately 25% of the subcontractors' applications had not been endorsed by main contractors. The main contractors' involvement has helped to reduce the incidence of abuse to some extent.

    Once foreign workers are brought in by the subcontractors on the support of main contractors, the subcontractors and main contractors would be accountable for the accommodation and placements of foreign workers should they be subsequently displaced. Main contractors have the resources to house workers abandoned by their subcontractors, or transfer their employment to other subcontractors within the same project or in other projects.

    It is thus not true that main contractors have no control over the foreign workers employed by the subcontractors. These foreign workers were brought in to work on their projects in the first instance. Therefore, requiring main contractors to share the responsibility with their subcontractors is necessary to avoid abuses and illegal practices.
